I don't think Randi hates people who engage in magical thinking, but he wishes they would open their eyes and use the brain that (so they think) God has given them.  Maybe he gets impatient with them, but that is not the same as hating them.

If you truly weighed the idea that DNA with billions of base pairs unwind from coils and supercoils in every one of you billions of cells to be decoded to make proteins and do so to make a beautiful baby in a universe with billions of stars in a single beautiful spiral galaxy, you might not make definitive statements like yours. And where may I ask is your consciousness residing in the coding of your DNA? Are you not awed by this like some of the greatest scientists?

That's all good, as long as you and parents like you, and your offspring, don't decide, 30 years down the road, that their neurological deficits are from high school football, and everybody must dole out millions of dollars to make it better.

executive orders can't trump the Constitution. Ask your kids.
That's a weed we don't have in the West.  It's a shame, because our butterflies would love it.
I see we just skipped right on past all the clashes between the AG and this President.

The best Attorney General of the past 50 years was, hands down, Edward Levi. President Ford appointed the President of the University of Chicago Law School as AG to restore public confidence after John Mitchell's resignation in disgrace. What made Levi so exceptional was his integrity, his commitment to the rule of law, his non-partisanship, and his lack of a political agenda.  That contrasts sharply with the usual AG, whose primary job has been to provide legal cover for the president and sometimes to advance the president's political agenda (e.g., Robert Kennedy, John Mitchell, Ed Meese, Eric Holder).  Let's all hope and pray that Loretta Lynch is cut out of the Edward Levi mold and not the Eric Holder mold.

Holder has been a disaster when it comes to financial crimes. Let us remember that he has only done--and not done--what the President wanted. It seems unlikely that U.S. Attorney Lynch will be any different in that regard--the last time an Attorney General refused to do the bidding of a President was Elliot Richardson, who resigned during the "Saturday Night Massacre" of 1973.

Remember she is the one who will steer the pardon process.  Remember Marc Rich and Eric Holder.  Of course no pardons will be done until December 2016.  What will happen is going to impact O's legacy more then anything else.

This piece describes a great criminal trial attorney with no experience in or taste for prosecuting complex cases of criminal wrongdoing committed by the pen rather than the knife. Although I'm very happy to see an actual prosecutor leading the Department of Justice it might have been nice to have appointed somebody with experience in ending the culture of impunity that the wealthy enjoy.

The AG position is both executive and administrative. Long-term, those might be more important skills than prosecutorial excellence. Ms. Lynch might do well, we don't know yet. But there are credentials required beyond being an excellent prosecutor that the AG post requires. Which is perhaps why she was not intially picked.
It's would make a lot of sense to fight Jesus' nomination - he'd make a lousy Attorney General.
Very well stated, sir. One of the as yet unheralded benefits of the recent election may be a gradual reassertion of states' rights.

While the dialogue between states has been integral to the Republic since its founding, and should go on forever, that specific phrase--"states' rights" has a long, ugly history that only begins with legitimating slavery.

Ms. Sanger-Katz makes the point that "It would just make federal spending on health care more uneven than it already is." To clarify, she is not speaking about any inequality between rich and poor and young and old but rather between so-called red and blue states.

This is certainly true. But why is this a bad thing ? It is certainly not unusual. There are a variety of state-specific responses to a variety of government services and provisions. In Texas, it is quite easy to get a license to carry a gun. In New York, where I live, it is far more difficult. Massachusetts provides government benefits for the needy that total over $40,000/person. They also have among the nation's highest tax rates as a consequence. Different states do things differently. And this idea called Federalism is consistent with the important principle of self-rule.

In this light, the idea of Obamacare itself is inconsistent with self-rule. The left likes to point out that Obamacare was first tried in Massachusetts by a Republican Governor. This may be true, but again, Massachusetts is one of the most liberal states in the nation. Why should its choices be forced upon the residents in more conservative Texas where Obamacare is extremely unpopular ? Many states like Texas also have no state income tax. How do you think the rest of the nation were to react if a Republican President decided to emulate Texas across the nation and disallow any state from having an income tax ?

Citing the economic gains of China as a model worthy of emulation is misleading, for a large fraction of that time their currency was pegged to the dollar making their exports artificially cheap.  Unfortunately this is fools gold.  History shows that this pattern leads to eras of secular stagnation as they attempt to devalue.

There is nothing funny about China feeding the move to species extinction when the species is as grand as the elephant, and China's leaders are more like cockroaches with credit cards. American corporate outsourcing is like a soup kitchen for Chinese cockroaches.

Though I felt sad about the elephants involved, the ivory episode struck me as sort of funny. You really expect Xi to care about elephants? He wouldn't lose any sleep even if all elephants disappeared from the Earth. He can look at his hoard of ivory and gloat.
The winds of change will buffet the World, Mr. Kristof. China is rising and may still rise more, but we can rise too. Conflict is not inevitable if enough space is given to aspirations on both sides. China will always be a strange land to us, and might become stranger in the future, with different power structures becoming stronger or weaker. But we can work with whoever is in charge, without trying to change the Chinese worldview. Respect for the rights of elephants and those of human beings come from the same source, as we learn to value life in all its aspects, and the Chinese leaders will eventually learn this lesson too. Maybe it will happen long after Xi and his ivory have turned into dust, but they will learn it on their own.

I hate to say this, but it is impossible for America avoid being poked in the eyes, now by Chinese but with equal probability by few more countries on the rapid rise.

Americans administrations exhibits unfortunate tendency of " blindness of superiority continues to hold the belief that all the vast regions of our planet should develop and mature to the level of contemporary Western systems, the best in theory and the most attractive in practice; that all those other worlds are but temporarily prevented (by wicked leaders or by severe crises or by their own barbarity and incomprehension) from pursuing Western pluralistic democracy and adopting the Western way of life." to quote Alexander Solzhenitsyn.

Senator J. William Fulbright hits the nail on the head saying, "America, if it can bring itself to act with the magnanimity and the empathy appropriate to its size and power, can be an intelligent example to the world. We have the opportunity to set an example of generous understanding in our relations with China, of practical cooperation for peace in our relations with Russia, of reliable and respectful partnership in our relations with Western Europe, of material helpfulness without moral presumption in our relations with the developing nations, of abstention from the temptations of hegemony in our relations with Latin America, and of the all- around advantages of minding one's own business in our relations with everybody. "
Melo led Denver to their best record ever and took then further into the playoffs than they'd ever been.

Let's make sure to correct the record here: The Nuggets didn't win a playoff series during the Melo era until Chauncey Billups joined him in Denver. And the Nuggets' best record ever was set in the 2012-13 season, when they won 57 games, well after Melo was traded to the Knicks.

Let's make sure to correct the record here. Yes. Melo had teammates in Denver. As for Billups, his best years were in Detroit. By the time he joined up with Melo. he was over the hill.

Melo led the Nuggets to their best record in their first 35 years in the NBA. That doesn't count their ABA years or the years since he left. He still holds the record for taking Denver furthest in the playoffs.

Most important, Oscar Robertson never got far in the playoffs with the Royals because his teams lacked talent. Exactly when has Melo played with anyone as good as the Big O's teammates?

It's easy math - as long as Melo in your number one star there will be no championship. What he did as Cuse was amazing but this is the NBA and he will never win at this level. There is no debate. That's a fact. Not as the number one -  never.  I am a former season ticket holder who gave up my seats this year.  What a great move.  Why given that kazoo playing clown Dolan another cent of my money? Instead I'm giving the money to charity. 41 yrs... Maybe they'll celebrate by winning 41 games (that's a stretch) and losing in five games in the first round of the playoffs. What a joke.

Chris I don't think that Mr. Araton's point was to de-emphasize the new system.  It reads more to me that he believes the organization should focus on creating a new culture in general and being in new (way more talented and smarter) players first.  Then make the triangle top priority.  Total waste of energy trying to work with a JR Smith, Bargnani, Shumpert.  Fix the roster first.

comments.commentBody:
Chris,
not really saying there should be no triangle. more that too much has been made of it, as if that alone is the answer, Spike Lee film and all (on MSG). that has obviously gotten into the players' heads, made them believe all success is predicated on mastering something that could take a couple for some players and perhaps never for others. i am suggesting there should have been more of a phase-in plan, especially given Anthony's history of difficulty of adaptability and the pressure on him to justify the new contract. the more Jackson players added, the more you can do with his system. check out how Cleamons and Rambis did with the triangle when they were head coaches. as i said, the focus this season should be on the establishment of a positive and cohesive working environment after so much dysfunction, top down. that -- more than the triangle itself -- is what will attract a Marc Gasol or a top-flight free agent.

Hello Harvey:

I am with Chris on this one. You suggest they should not emphasize the triangle, but what alternative are you proposing? They have a new coach and they want to implement a new system and culture. What should the start date be? How about right now?

Also, I am disappointed by this coverage of last night's game. There is a major issue around point guard and I see no mention of Shane Larkin, who has been on and off as starter. It is too early in the season to be providing late-season, out-of-the-playoff game coverage.

Cheers,

Jeff Pucillo

I am surprised that Araton, a smart basketball analyst, is suggesting the Knicks, who have not had a philosophical system since the Riley/Van Gundy administration, think about demphasizing the system four games in.  This type of short term thinking is what has made the 21st Century a debacle for the Knicks.  Phil Jackson is not only trying to install a system, he is trying to create a culture.  He will not undo 15 years of damage in 2 weeks. Thinking about demphasizing  a system after a few bad games is something we expect to hear from the Craig Cartons of the world, not Harvey Araton.

Other than Carmelo, Knicks do not now have a player who would be starting on a good team.  We'll see about Calderon.  System schmistem.  It's about talent, and despite their payroll, the Knicks don't have anywhere near enough.  It's going to be a long season.  Please, somebody see if Charles Oakley or Anthony Mason will come out of retirement; someone who is tough and can rebound.
MANDATORY voting. Paper ballots.

Yes - Yes - Yes. It works !
In Australia it's not perfect, but overall, it works !!
And has done so for over 100 years. It starts with compulsory enrolment at age 18yo. So much easier to manage, at both State and Federal level.

Einstein is correct in thinking mandatory voting and paper ballots are the way to go. However  mandatory voting would take a response from congress and, given their track record and personal investment in low voter turnout, that is currently unlikely. So until that can happen, as in Australia, we need to start the voter movement now for 2016.  Hopefully, Einstein's vision will materialize sooner rather than later.

Given the focus of this editorial, what are the available options to curb this type of spending?  It is unlikely that the Supreme Court will change this situation. In the past when the Supreme Court made a grievous error there was a constitutional amendment to correct the damage (e.g, the Dred Scott decision). If 2/3 of the populace stay away from the polls because of apathy and disgust for the politicians it is unlikely that there will be a constitutional change. It seems that the only way to change things is to get the voters to the polls (or post office). This doesn't take as much money as the attack ads. But it takes time and grass roots organization that needs to start now if we want a different turnout in 2016.

Dear Mr. Ed. Boarders...
There's a fairly simple way to "get money out of politics," and that is to open the floodgates--all money, all the time. With a Best Friends With Financial Benefits Act, we would allow anything and everything "of financial benefit to be donated by human beings to our elected employees. This includes money, meals, nocturnal companions, land, jobs, failure to regulate, failure to prosecute, you name it.
The quid-pro-quo: Donor and donees must be identified on both sides of the equation, and the donations must be updated every night, overnight, like check clearinghouse activities. And every bill, and every regulation, must contain a Section 2: Statement of Financial Benefits, listing donors, donees, and the anticipated financial benefit to be realized from the bill or regulation if passed (or if killed). And by whom. The financial benefits would be tracked through their lifetime.
Companion legislation: The ROPI Accounting Act, which sets up the lobbyist and other donor accounts, and the donee accounts. Maybe the FEC could expand its role. A companion ROPI Windfall Profits Tax would allow ROPI up to the prime interest rate. Above that would be considered a windfall, and taxed at 100%.
Enforcement for filing fraud, misidentification or late filing: a fine of at least 100 times the financial benefit in play, and a prison term of twice the number of years the donee has served. Example: If the lapse involved someone like the late Sen. Byrd, 100 years.

Considering moving to Mexico or Argentina, where no one pretends politics is open and honest. It will be decades before we have even a remote chance of developing effective limits on campaign spending and 'dark money.' Every time I read a story of the selling of the American political system I feel a need to wash my hands.

"Dark money" has helped win the Senate and the House and the White House since the birth of the nation. With the form of the monetary donation contribution triumphing over the substance. Going well beyond the mere appearance of impropriety into blatant corruption and quid pro quo bribery.

Money is not speech. Nor is money a vote. And "dark money" is not donated to politicians and political parties and advocacy organizations out of altruism and philanthropy. Both political parties solicit and accept big business corporate plutocrat money singing different rhetorical hymns from the same practical hymn book.

China and Russia are both trying to emulate our corrupt crony capitalist socioeconomic political model with their own exceptional unique ethnic sectarian national myths. Should we be horrified or flattered?

As long as Americans can continue to delude themselves into believing that we are all divinely created equal with certain unalienable rights in "a sweet land of liberty" and "the land of the free and the home of the brave" singing "God bless America" then the "dark money" will have served it's primary purpose. Buy the people with fear and hate and division and the politicians will certainly follow.

In dissecting the Democrats' drubbing last Tuesday, most of the analysis seems to have focused on secretive sources of cash and its disproportionate advantage for the GOP, as though the outcome would have been much less bleak if only the Democrats had wangled more funds from donors. Left largely unexamined were their inadequacies regarding political strategies, organizations skills, and party-wide discipline. Blaming their ignominious defeat on their opponents' fund-raising prowess will only put off the day of reckoning when Democrats face the critical need for overhauling their management of political campaigns. Attention liberals: Dark money seems to be a permanent feature of the new political landscape. Deal with it!
